title: KeenWrite 3.3.1
description:
KeenWrite 3.3.1 contains the following updates since the 3.2.0 release, including:

  • Specify chapter ranges via the command-line.
  • Set R bootstrap file via the command-line.
  • Add ability to export directory (of files) to HTML.
  • Numerous library and security updates.
  • Integration of SpotBugs into the build, along with fixes for nearly all its findings.
  • Performance improvements from migrating to JDK 20.
  • Relative image path and extensions.

The way Markdown image references work better reflects how ConTeXt allows referencing images in TeX files. The images can be relative to a directory that‚Äôs specified at build time. Similarly, the image extensions can be prioritized up in a specific order (e.g., svg, pdf, png, then jpg). For example, writing the following image tag in a Markdown document will place the image into the final PDF file, even if the image path is /home/username/story/images/animals/kitten.png:

![kitten](kitten)

When building the document, either from the command-line or the GUI, the ‚Äúimage directory‚Äù must be set accordingly. Allowing filename extension detection allows for graceful degrading of quality.

I started developing KeenWrite because I could find no text editors or word processors that allowed me to quickly and easily reference variables within documents. KeenWrite allows users to reference externally defined variables throughout the document. The variables can use the popular mustache format ({{ }}) or an R-specific syntax (to help create living documents).

For a preview of what else KeenWrite can do, see the video tutorials.
description_plain:
KeenWrite 3.3.1 contains the following updates since the 3.2.0 release, including:

* Specify chapter ranges via the command-line.
* Set R bootstrap file via the command-line.
* Add ability to export directory (of files) to HTML.
* Numerous library and security updates.
* Integration of [SpotBugs](https://github.com/spotbugs/spotbugs) into the build, along with fixes for nearly all its findings.
* Performance improvements from migrating to JDK 20.
* Relative image path and extensions.

The way Markdown image references work better reflects how ConTeXt allows referencing images in TeX files. The images can be relative to a directory that's specified at build time. Similarly, the image extensions can be prioritized up in a specific order (e.g., `svg`, `pdf`, `png`, then `jpg`). For example, writing the following image tag in a Markdown document will place the image into the final PDF file, even if the image path is `/home/username/story/images/animals/kitten.png`:

 `![kitten](kitten)`

When building the document, either from the command-line or the GUI, the "image directory" must be set accordingly. Allowing filename extension detection allows for graceful degrading of quality.

I started developing KeenWrite because I could find no text editors or word processors that allowed me to quickly and easily reference variables within documents. KeenWrite allows users to reference externally defined variables throughout the document. The variables can use the popular mustache format (`{{ }}`) or an R-specific syntax (to help create living documents).

For a preview of what else KeenWrite can do, see the [video tutorials](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLB-WIt1cZYLm1MMx2FBG9KWzPIoWZMKu_).
